item.title: Shadow & Claw
item.description: I think a series that has its own [[books/lexicon urthus|lexicon]] counts for the ultimate feat of [[notes/puzzle-book worldbuilding|puzzle-book worldbuilding]].

item.title: The Sorcerer of the Wildeeps
item.description: Whoa. Masterful use of dialect and structure to deconstruct the traditional bounds of genre and narrative. The way the characters code-switch their way through multiple registers and languages—well-known and invented—is reflected in the way the novella flips through genres like a catalog, exposing the expectations and limitations of each.

item.title: A Taste of Honey
item.description: That ending! Talk about an ending that twists everything you thought you read for the previous 159 pages (I dare say, happily so).

item.title: Sword & Citadel
item.description: Ugh, my [[notes/puzzle-book worldbuilding|puzzle-loving brain]] absolutely loved this. Even all the places where it was like, Gene, your Roman Catholicism is showing.

item.title: The Left Hand of Darkness
item.description: Imperfect and still utterly perfect. Favorite always. The David Mitchell foreword Picture if you will reading this book when it was published, 1969, the year of Stonewall

item.title: The Dispossessed
item.description: Sublime. Carefully constructed, nuanced, warmly empathetic, passionately human, complex. If you want a rose-colored ideologue that purports to fix problems with simplistic utopias, look elsewhere.

item.title: Always Coming Home
item.description: I’ve been saving this one because [[notes/the carrier bag theory of fiction|the Carrier Bag Theory of Fiction]] has been such a foundational text for me, and this is where Ursula, more than ever, puts that theory to practice.

item.title: Among Others
item.description: “[[notes/bibliotropic|Bibliotropic]],” Hugh said. “Like sunflowers are heliotropic, they naturally turn towards the sun. We naturally turn towards the bookshop.”

item.title: The Found and the Lost
item.description: Le Guin is the master of the novella. Each of these stories contains a universe; even the stories meant to expand the worlds she’s created in her [[series/hainish cycle|Hainish]] and [[series/earthsea cycle|Earthsea]] cycles, they feel complete unto themselves.

item.title: The Twice-Drowned Saint
item.description: I don’t even know how the hell to describe this, except amazing. Apparently my unintentional theme lately is biblically accurate angels—see [[books/pet|Pet]], see [[books/exodus 20|Freydís Moon]].

item.title: The Word for World is Forest
item.description: This is how I like a thinly-veiled parable to work, especially an anti-colonialism one. (There’s barely any need for fiction; it’s Vietnam.
